INT 10.title: Transitioning to Academic Excellence
INT 10.description: This course bridges the experiential and cognitive transitions necessary for academic success at UCSB. Lectures address the practical skills and tools necessary to achieve academic success while also addressing the affective impact of adjusting to the expectations, norms, and rigor of a research university.

INT 20.title: Introduction to The Research University
INT 20.description: Through reading, videos, and writing, students in this course are introduced to disciplines and activities at the core of the research university. Students learn about the form and function of the research university; understand how natural science, social science, humanities and fine arts, and interdisciplinary programs are situated, and develop a plan for engaging in undergraduate research as part of their UCSB experiences.

INT 24.title: Promoting Transfer Student Success Through Engagement
INT 24.description: Explores best practices related to student success in college. Students will summarize research on student success, and discuss research-led programming and/or interventions. The discussions are aimed at increasing student involvement in high impact practices.

INT 33AAZZ.title: Discovery Seminar
INT 33AAZZ.description: Discovery Seminars provide opportunity to learn more about focused subjects with UCSB's distinguished faculty. Each Discovery Seminar will include three faculty from different disciplines who will share with students their perspectives on the subject, and also help students understand how faculty within their disciplines do the work of asking and investigating questions about these subjects. Students in the seminars will both develop their knowledge of the subject, and develop deeper understandings of how learning about disciplinary interests and perspectives can help them to become more effective learners.

INT 33G.title: Brave New World: Perspectives on Gene Manipulation

INT 33H.title: Looking Under the Hood: Studying the University

INT 35AAZZ.title: Exploring the Arts and Humanities
INT 35AAZZ.description: Courses in this series provide students an immersive experience that combines focus on a particular discipline in the Humanities with research and a performing and/or fine art or other additive experience. This integrative approach introduces students to how various disciplines explore, contextualize and creatively articulate the human experience.

INT 35DS.title: The Past Haunts the Present: Ancient Values and Modern   Interactions

INT 36AAZZ.title: Engaging Humanities Learning Community
INT 36AAZZ.description: Courses focused on innovative topics, ways of thinking, and career applications of humanities disciplines. Students engage in extensive reading, writing, and collaborative activity to explore ideas and develop their own thinking.

INT 36BH.title: Writing About, For, and With Bodies

INT 36CC.title: Celebrating the City: Carnivals, Processions, and Other Urban Rituals

INT 36GS.title: How Games Tell Stories (and What We Learn From Them)

INT 36KX.title: Disability Aesthetics and Politics in Chinese Literature and Western Music

INT 36LH.title: Listening in the Humanities: Sound Studies @UCSB

INT 36MM.title: Moors, Mongols, and the Monstrous: Race and Racism in the Middle Ages

INT 38.title: Designing ePortfolios: Reflection, Integration, and Presentation
INT 38.description: Students in the Engaging Humanities program create ePortfolios that translate between their identities as students and their emerging identities as professionals. Students will collect artifacts and organize those artifacts to feature skills and expertise. Then, students will reflect upon their coursework and the skills developed in curricular and extracurricular activities. Then, students will organize, compose, and design professional ePortfolios that feature their unique skills, expertise, and experience for professional audiences.

INT 45.title: Study Abroad Leadership Practicum
INT 45.description: Students develop their leadership skills in the study abroad field through weekly group meetings, problem solving, and project development. They will focus on assessing current and future co-curricular activities offered by the UC Education Abroad Program. Examples of topics include making academic planning and advising more effective, student finances, experiential learning opportunities, developing marketing strategies, enhancing diversity, inclusion, and equity. Students reflect on their experiential learning about leadership through dialogue and ongoing reflective practice. Required activities include project development and implementation.

INT 64.title: Career Development and Decision Making Theory and Practice
INT 64.description: Provides an overview of theoretical constructs of career development and practical applications from college across the lifespan. Through lectures, readings, discussions, and projects, the course assists students in developing an effective life plan while exploring majors at college and career choices.

INT 75.title: Underserved Medicine
INT 75.comments:
Quarters usually offered: Winter.
Repeat Comments: Students who have completed MCDB 194MD are not eligible to take INT 75.
INT 75.description: Explores unique medical needs of vulnerable, underserved populations internationally and locally by using service and problem-based learning methodologies.  Topics include refugee health, homelessness, humanitarian aid in conflict zones, veterans care, global health development, migrant farm workers care, and more.

INT 75H.title: Seminar for Underserved Medicine
INT 75H.prereq_description: Concurrent enrollment in INT 75; enrollment in Letters and Science Honors Program, or consent of instructor.
INT 75H.description: A seminar course for a select number of students enrolled in INT 75 designed to enrich the experience for the motivated student.

INT 84AAZZ.title: Introductory Honors Seminar: Special Topics
INT 84AAZZ.prereq_description: Enrollment in Letters and Science Honors Program.
INT 84AAZZ.description: Provides an introduction to research and scholarship on current issues of national and/or international concern.

INT 84CX.title: Honors Seminar: Plant, Drug, Weed: Cannabis and World History

INT 84CY.title: Honors Seminar: Food, Science, and Cooking

INT 84CZ.title: Honors Seminar: Introduction to Data Science and Machine Learning: Foundations and Applications

INT 85.title: Introduction to University Research
INT 85.description: Introduces freshman honors students to research opportunities at UCSB. Professors from different academic disciplines will come to share their own college experiences, their research interests, and their involvement in undergraduate teaching and research, while upper class honors students will showcase their research projects and discuss ways to approach and work with professors. All freshman honors students are encouraged to enroll.

INT 86.title: Introduction to Research: from Citizen Science to Digital Humanities
INT 86.description: Introduces freshman honors students to research opportunities at UCSB. Professors from different academic disciplines will come to share their own college experiences, their research interests, and their involvement in undergraduate teaching and research, while advanced students will showcase their research projects and discuss ways to approach and work with professors.  In addition, students will engage in several ongoing research projects from the sciences to the humanities.  The major challenge of 21st century research is dealing with the flood of information now collected. Computers can help, but in many fields the human ability for pattern recognition is required.

INT 88AAZZ.title: Second Year Exploration Seminars
INT 88AAZZ.comments: Students may earn a maximum of 3 units from all INT 88AA-ZZ courses. No seminars with the same suffix (AA-ZZ) may be repeated.
INT 88AAZZ.description: Selected topics of interest to students pursuing various degrees in the College of Letters and Science. Small group discussions which emphasize active class participation. Topics vary each quarter.

INT 88AI.title: Second Year Discovery Seminar: Social Innovation: Tools for Changemakers

INT 88AJ.title: Second Year Discovery Seminar: Regeneration: Exhibiting Black Cinema

INT 88AK.title: Second Year Discovery Seminar: Asian American Intergenerational Conflict

INT 89AAZZ.title: First Year Discovery & Linked Seminars
INT 89AAZZ.description: First year seminars that provide opportunity for students to investigate a single topic from two different disciplinary perspectives (Discovery), or in significant depth (Linked).

INT 90M.title: Research and Professional Development for NcNair Scholars
INT 90M.description: Introduction to research skills for faculty-mentored research projects for McNair Scholars in the sciences, humanities, and social sciences.  Lectures, discussions, faculty visits and presentation of research in McNair Symposium are included.

INT 91AAZZ.title: Interdisciplinary Issues: Special Topics
INT 91AAZZ.description: A seminar-style course examining interdisciplinary issues in various fields.

INT 93LS.title: Introduction to Research in STEM, Humanities, and Social Sciences
INT 93LS.comments:
Quarters usually offered: Summer. May be repeated for credit provided topicand project are different; offered summer only.
Repeat Comments: May be repeated for credit provided topic and project are different.
INT 93LS.description: Introduction to university-level research experiences in STEM, Humanities, and Social Sciences disciplines. Students participate in project based, directed research while learning about current practices and trends. The course culminates with a group presentation and submission of findings.

INT 93P.title: Presentation Techniques in Interdisciplinary University   Research
INT 93P.description: Introduction to presentation techniques in interdisciplinary research for students working in research projects. Oral/poster presentation methods, elevator pitch techniques. Exposure to a variety of research projects by way of lectures given by researchers who are leaders in their fields.

INT 93R.title: Introduction to Interdisciplinary University Research   Techniques
INT 93R.description: Introduction to University level interdisciplinary research writing techniques for students working on research projects this summer.  Abstract, introduction, research goals/methods, discussion and results.  Reference style techniques.  Hands-on guided research experience in laboratories and/or libraries for all disciplines.

INT 93S.title: Readings and Lectures in the Social, Life, and Physical   Sciences
INT 93S.comments: Hours adjusted for Summer Sessions, offered in summer only.
INT 93S.description: Introductory course for students interested in research in the social, life or physical sciences. Students read papers written by and about recent research at UCSB and meet with researchers to discuss their research tools and concepts.

INT 94AAZZ.title: First Year Exploration Seminars
INT 94AAZZ.comments: Students may earn a maximum of 3 units from all INT 94AA-ZZ courses. No seminars with the same suffix (AA-ZZ) may be repeated.
INT 94AAZZ.description: Selected topics of interest to students pursuing various degrees in the College of Letters and Science. Small group discussions which emphasize active class participation. Topics will vary each quarter.

INT 94WN.title: First Year Discovery Seminar: The (Bio)Chemistry of Food

INT 95AAZZ.title: The Modern Research University: Pathways to Discovery and   Creativity
INT 95AAZZ.comments: May be repeated for additional credit provided the letter designations are different.
INT 95AAZZ.description: Introduces students to the nature of research in the various disciplines represented at UCSB through weekly lectures by faculty artists, engineers, humanists, scientists, and social scientists speaking about their creative or scholarly research projects.

INT 96AAZZ.title: Major Discovery Seminar
INT 96AAZZ.description: Major Discovery Seminars are intended for students to explore new or additional majors. Seminars help students to understand how different disciplines explore subjects. Seminars focus on one contemporary issue or question explored by multiple faculty.

INT 97AAZZ.title: Second Year Discovery & Linked Seminars
INT 97AAZZ.comments: Students may earn a maximum of 6 units from all INT 97AA-ZZ courses. No seminars with the same suffix (AA-ZZ) may be repeated.
INT 97AAZZ.description: Second year seminars that provide opportunity for students to investigate a single topic from two different disciplinary perspectives (Discovery), or in significant depth (Linked).

INT 98RA.title: Introduction to Research
INT 98RA.comments: Students are limited to 5 units per quarter and 30 units in all 98/99/198/199/199AA-ZZ courses combined.
INT 98RA.description: Introduction to research for College of Letters and Science students participating in the Faculty Research Assistance Program (FRAP) under the guidance of a faculty mentor.  Course offers students the opportunity to work in a research group.

INT 101.title: Legal Career and Law School Lecture/Workshop Series
INT 101.description: Combining lectures and workshops this upper-division course covers a range of topics on the legal profession and law school application process.

INT 102.title: Emerging Adulthood - Transitions
INT 102.description: Addresses adulting from the perspective of college student development with a focus on transitions and growth during college and in preparation for life after college. Topics will include career exploration, preparation for graduate school, the importance of social networks and building social capital, beliefs and values, and relationships and emotional resiliency in different contexts.

INT 111AAZZ.title: Entering STEM Disciplines
INT 111AAZZ.comments: Quarters usually offered: Summer. For students in the Transfer Summer StartProgram only.
INT 111AAZZ.description: Transfer students will develop successful approaches and orientations to study of STEM disciplines. Students required to attend regular lectures and discussions; form and participate in study groups; and meet with faculty members and departmental advisors regularly. Assignment(s) will require each student to demonstrate that each of these activities has led to a more thorough understanding requirements for success in the discipline.

INT 112E.title: Entering Economics
INT 112E.comments: Quarters usually offered: Summer. For students in the Transfer Summer StartProgram only.
INT 112E.description: Transfer students will develop successful approaches and orientations to study of the Economics disciplines. Students required to attend regular lectures and discussions; form and participate in study groups; and meet with faculty members and departmental advisors regularly. Assignment(s) will require each student to demonstrate that each of these activities has led to a more thorough understanding requirements for success in the discipline.

INT 125.title: Studying and Supporting University Learning
INT 125.comments: This course is open only to peer mentors in participating departments.
INT 125.description: This course focuses on theories and practices associated with successful postsecondary mentoring. This includes an overview of theories associated with student learning, of effective mentoring and pedagogy, and of student development. Each week of the course, we'll focus on one of these areas. We'll discuss key ideas from some of the foundational literature, discuss its use in practice, and reflect on experiences of that use.

INT 126.title: Training for Undergraduate Mentoring
INT 126.description: Course focuses on research-based approaches to academic mentoring. Students will receive intensive training in learning and development theory, mentoring techniques, and approaches to working with others. Students will gain knowledge and skills to help them in their roles as mentors to others as part of their work in the Undergraduate Mentoring Program.

INT 133AAZZ.title: Interdisciplinary Humanities Lab
INT 133AAZZ.comments: Course may be repeated as long as letter designations are different.
INT 133AAZZ.description: An interdisciplinary, team-taught course exploring the scientific, social, literary, and artistic dimensions of given topics (e.g., memory, gender, food). It offers a closely mentored, active learning experience centering on independent projects informed by interdisciplinary methods, theories and materials.

INT 136AAZZ.title: Engaging Humanities Learning Community for Transfer Students
INT 136AAZZ.prereq_description: Transfer students only; consent of instructor.
INT 136AAZZ.description: Courses focused on innovative topics, ways of thinking, and career applications of humanities disciplines. Students engage in extensive reading, writing, and collaborative activity to explore ideas and develop their own thinking.

INT 137AAZZ.title: Engaging Humanities Discovery Course
INT 137AAZZ.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 8 units provided letter designations are different.
INT 137AAZZ.description: Students will explore cross-disciplinary questions from the perspective of humanities and fine arts disciplines. Courses will involve lecture, active learning, and writing.

INT 175.title: Health Care Delivery
INT 175.description: This unique course is directed to those upper division students interested in health professions and who should understand the important issues related to health care delivery in the US. Guest speakers will address the economics and models of health care delivery as well as other topics to include quality control, the Affordable Care Act, the ethics in decision making and more.

INT 176.title: Introduction to Clinical Medicine
INT 176.description: For students interested in careers in the health profession.  Presenters from UCLA Health will help students understand the systemic environment and career considerations as they relate to healthcare delivery in the U.S.

INT 176LA.title: UCLA Health Shadowing
INT 176LA.prereq_description: INT 176; upper-division standing and consent of instructor
INT 176LA.description: Facilitates watching and listening during patient histories, physical examinations, procedures, surgeries, teaching rounds, and/or educational activities. This course does not include participation in direct or indirect patient care or management, nor constitute formal medical training.

INT 177AAZZ.title: Senior Transfer Discovery & Linked Seminars
INT 177AAZZ.comments: Students may earn a maximum of 6 units from all INT 177AA-ZZ course.
INT 177AAZZ.description: Seminars that provide opportunity for transfer students to investigate a single topic from two different disciplinary perspectives (Discovery), or in significant depth (Linked). Topics vary each quarter.

INT 184AAZZ.title: Honors Seminar: Special Topics
INT 184AAZZ.prereq_description: Enrollment in Letters and Science Honors Program; upper-division standing.
INT 184AAZZ.comments:
May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 8 units provided letter designations are different.
Repeat Comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 8 units provided letter designations are different.
INT 184AAZZ.description: An interdisciplinary approach to topics of national and world concerns. Readings will be assigned from several disciplinary perspectives.

INT 184ZS.title: Honors Seminar: Special Topics
INT 184ZS.prereq_description: Enrollment in Letters and Science Honors Program; upper-division
INT 184ZS.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 8 units provided letter designations are different.
INT 184ZS.description: An interdisciplinary approach to topics of national and world concerns. Readings will be assigned from several disciplinary perspectives.

INT 185AAZZ.title: Interdisciplinary Humanities Seminar
INT 185AAZZ.description: Seminar hosted by the Interdisciplinary Humanities Center (IHC) and focused on selected topics, texts, theories, and/or methods in the humanities. See IHC website (www.ihc.ucsb.edu) for current listings.

INT 186AAZZ.title: Transfer Exploration Seminars
INT 186AAZZ.description: Selected topics of interest to students pursuing various degrees in the College of Letters and Science. Small group discussions which emphasize active class participation. Topics will vary each quarter.

INT 187AAZZ.title: Transfer Discovery & Linked Seminars
INT 187AAZZ.description: Seminars that provide opportunity for transfer students to investigate a single topic from two different disciplinary perspectives (Discovery), or in significant depth (Linked). Topics will vary each quarter.

INT 188.title: Promoting Research Engagement-REU Application Development
INT 188.description: This course explores best practices for student engagement in undergraduate research. Students will develop and prepare materials for a research program application. The discussions are aimed at creating a learning community for promoting undergraduate research across campus, with a focus on students interested in developing an REU application for programs like McNair. The McNair office will be sponsoring this course.

INT 189AAZZ.title: Senior Transfer Exploration Seminars
INT 189AAZZ.comments: Students may earn a maximum of 3 units from all INT 189AA-ZZ courses. No seminars with the same suffix (AA-ZZ) may be repeated.
INT 189AAZZ.description: Selected topics of interest to students pursuing various degrees in the College of Letters and Science. Small group discussions which emphasize active class participation. Topics vary each quarter.

INT 190MA.title: Junior Seminar for McNair Scholars
INT 190MA.prereq_description: Admission to McNair Scholars Program; junior standing.
INT 190MA.description: Development of proposals for research in collaboration with faculty and McNair staff.  Group discussion of research approaches, post-baccalaureate career preparation, and planning for entrance to doctoral study.

INT 190MB.title: Senior Seminar for McNair Scholars
INT 190MB.prereq_description: Admission to McNair Scholars Program; senior standing.
INT 190MB.comments:
Quarters usually offered: Winter, Spring, Fall.
Repeat Comments: Course can be taken in fall, winter, and spring of senior year for a maximum of 6.0 units.
INT 190MB.description: Students gain familiarity with the key elements of the graduate school application process, apply to selected graduate schools, engage in collaborative reading and writing, and prepare research for presentation at academic and professional meetings.

INT 192DC.title: Washington Center Internship
INT 192DC.prereq_description: Upper-division standing; consent of instructor; acceptance to Washington Center.
INT 192DC.description: Courses designed for students to obtain credit for internship while at the Washington Center.

INT 192SA.title: Sacramento Center Internship
INT 192SA.prereq_description: Upper-division standing; consent of instructor; acceptance to Sacramento Center.
INT 192SA.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 8 units.
INT 192SA.description: Courses designed for students to obtain credit for internship while at the UC Sacramento Center.

INT 193.title: Research at the Capital: Immigration Policy and Public Service
INT 193.comments: Open to current and prospective UCDC students only.
INT 193.description: This seminar guides student research as they prepare for, and participate in, the UCDC Program based in the nation's capital.  Students interested in immigration policy or in public service are encouraged to enroll. During fall quarter, each student will select a research topic, identify sources and methods, and write an application for UCSB's Undergraduate Research and Creative Activities (URCA) grant, to be submitted in early November. Winter or spring UCDC students will conduct research after they arrive in the capital. Students are eligible for additional credits (up to 4 units per qtr) to finish writing. Projects should be completed in the spring. A symposium will be held in April. URCA recipients present in the colloquium in May.

INT 194NP.title: American Indian and Indigenous Proseminar
INT 194NP.description: This pro-seminar is focused on American Indian and Indigenous Studies. Taught in tandem with the graduate course, INT 594NP, this seminar includes narrative, film, poetry, visual arts, and theory. Since the syllabus content changes every quarter, this seminar can be taken multiple times and is designed to count for the AIIS Minor. Our community is inclusive and welcomes engaged discussion.

INT 197HC.title: Honors Contract
INT 197HC.description: Coursework shall consist of academic research supervised by a faculty member to deepen and broaden the student's experience in an upper division course in which the student is concurrently enrolled.

INT 197HI.title: Health Sciences Internship
INT 197HI.prereq_description: Upper-division students only; consent of instructor.
INT 197HI.description: Health internship approved for credit by and under the auspices of the Dean of Undergraduate Education.

INT 199D.title: Dean's Supervised Independent Study
INT 199D.description: Independent studies for students in the College of Letters and Science under the auspices of the Dean of Undergraduate Education.

INT 199DC.title: Independent Research At Washington Center
INT 199DC.prereq_description: Upper-division standing; consent of instructor; acceptance to Washington Center.
INT 199DC.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 8 units. Students are limited to5 units per quarter and 30 units total in all 98/99/198/199/199AA-ZZ courses combined.
INT 199DC.description: Independent research for those enrolled in the Washington Center. Enrolled students will complete a research project related to the students' internship and drawing on the special resources of the Washington area.

INT 199H.title: Honors Independent Studies
INT 199H.prereq_description: Upper-division Letters & Science Honors Program students only.

INT 199SA.title: Independent Research at Sacramento Center
INT 199SA.prereq_description: Upper-division standing; consent of instructor; acceptance to Sacramento Center.
INT 199SA.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 8 units. Students are limited1 to 5 units per quarter and 30 units total in all 98/99/198/199/199AA-ZZ courses combined.
INT 199SA.description: Independent research for those enrolled in the UC Sacramento Center. Enrolled students complete a research project related to the students' internship and drawing on the special resources of the Sacramento area.

INT 200.title: Seminar in Information Technology & Society
INT 200.description: Graduate seminar hosted by the Center for Information Technology & Society (CITS) on interdisciplinary topics, issues, theories, and methods concerning information technology and society. Serves as gateway course to the interdisciplinary PhD Emphasis in Technology & Society and is open to students in participating departments. See CITS website for more information (www.cits.ucsb.edu/education).

INT 200A.title: Seminar in Cognitive Science
INT 200A.description: Overview and introduction to topics in cognitive science.

INT 201AAZZ.title: Graduate Humanities Seminar
INT 201AAZZ.description: Graduate seminar hosted by the Interdisciplinary Humanities Center (IHC) on topics, texts, theories, and methods in the humanities. See IHC website for current listings (www.ihc.ucsb.edu).

INT 236.title: Engaging Humanities Mentoring Course
INT 236.description: This series of seminars is an introduction to mentoring for future graduate mentors. Topics covered include best practices, academic mentoring, career awareness building, and mentoring "soft skills." The group will also collaboratively compile mentoring resources and unpack different mentoring scenarios.

INT 295I.title: Public Humanities Practicum
INT 295I.description: The Public Humanities Practicum includes internships and fellow-designed community projects. It enables Ph.D. students to apply their academic training in community settings and develop skills such as oral and written communication for broad audiences; project design, management, and assessment; and grant-writing and program development for non-profit organizations. Students will receive one to four units of academic credit per quarter, depending on the length of the internship or project. Oversight will be provided by a mentor at the host organization and a UCSB faculty member.

INT 594AAZZ.title: Directed Reading and Research
INT 594AAZZ.description: In-depth consideration of interdisciplinary humanistic topics, issues, and concerns through tutorial format. Students may affiliate with Interdisciplinary Humanities Center's Research Focus Groups (www.ihc.ucsb.edu/research).

INT 596.title: Capstone
INT 596.prereq_description: For students in the Public Humanities Graduate Fellows Program only.
INT 596.description: The capstone project enables students to present their work in a public forum. Students can meet this requirement in a number of ways, for example, through a social media campaign, the publication of an op-ed piece, the creation of a public exhibit, or the staging of a public dialogue. In addition to the public-facing presentation, students will create a portfolio that includes a reflection piece about the professional attributes of the project.

INT CS 10.title: Group Interdisciplinary Studies
INT CS 10.comments: May be taken as often as once each quarter.
INT CS 10.description: Group studies in an interdisciplinary area. Supervised by a member of the faculty of the college of creative studies.

INT CS 20.title: Advanced Group Interdisciplinary Studies
INT CS 20.description: Advanced group studies in focussed topics in an interdisciplinary area, supervised by a member of the faculty of the College of Creative Studies.

INT CS 120.title: Advanced Group Interdisciplinary Studies
INT CS 120.description: Advanced group studies in focussed topics in an interdisciplinary area.

INT W 20.title: Introduction to The Research University
INT W 20.description: Through reading, videos, and writing, students in this course will be introduced to disciplines and activities at the core of the research university. Students will learn about the form and function of the research university; understand how natural science, social science, humanities and fine arts, and interdisciplinary programs are situated, and develop a plan for engaging in undergraduate research as part of their UCSB experiences.

INT W 22.title: International Student Experience at the Research University
INT W 22.description: Introduces international students to the varying disciplines of study and research opportunities available at UCSB.

INT W 120.title: Transferring to the Research University
INT W 120.description: This fully online course introduces incoming transfer students to the varying disciplines of study and research opportunities available at UCSB. The course delivers a series of videos featuring UCSB faculty detailing their specific discipline, and explaining how research is conducted within the discipline. Videos also include professional and personal information about faculty members' interest in the area of study. Transfer students will learn about their selected major (if previously determined) and have opportunities to consider additional majors/minors, and research interests.

INT W 188C.title: Transfer Exploration Seminar: Ways of Thinking and Practicing in Communication
INT W 188C.prereq_description: Instructor approval required prior to registration.
INT W 188C.description: Introduction to the academic discipline of communication with emphasis on scientific theoretical and methodological issues relevant to the systematic inquiry and pursuit of knowledge about human communication.

INT W 188E.title: Transfer Start Seminar: Economics
INT W 188E.prereq_description: Instructor approval required prior to registration.
INT W 188E.description: This course will consist of 12 videos, each followed by a set of questions to test comprehension and understanding of the video. The first video listed in each week is meant to teach economics content, while the second is generally meant to help students understand what is necessary to succeed in economics in an R1 research university. Each week of videos and assignments is expected to require about 1.5 hours to complete. Although the standard completion rate for the videos is two per week, students can complete the videos and assignments at their own pace, as long as they are completed in the six week session.
